Graphical abstract The main group of metal materials with electrocatalytic activity show high selectivity and stability for nitrogen reduction reaction. By designing reasonable and effective catalysts, the nitrogen reduction activity of the catalyst can be significantly improved. Therefore, the main group of metal-based catalysts have great potential in electrocatalytic nitrogen fixation. Electrocatalytic N2 reduction under ambient-condition is considered to be the most appealing strategy to the conventional Haber-Bosch process for synthetic ammonia to alleviate greenhouse emissions and reduce environmental pollution, mainly powered by renewable energy. Recent years, rapid advances have been gained in this attractive research field, and numerous electrocatalysts have been exploited. However, its conversion efficiency is still far behind the requirement of industrial applications owing to the breakage of the N≡N triple bond, which is an energetically challenging kinetically complex multistep reaction and the strong competing reaction of hydrogen evolution reaction. Recently, main group metal-based catalysts have been demonstrated promising application prospect for ammonia production, significantly boosting their further application in this field. However, a comprehensive review of main group metal-based catalysts towards electrochemical ammonia production applications is still lacking. In this review, the fundamentals of N2 reduction, such as the reaction pathways, the reaction potential and the challenges of N2 reduction have been comprehensively discussed. And then, the role, mechanism, and effect of each main group element-based catalysts used for N2 reduction (Li, K, Al, Ga, Sn, Sb, Bi, and their compounds) are systematically summarized. Finally, several state-of-the-art strategies to promote their NRR catalytic performance, as well as the existing problems and prospects are put forward. This review is expected to guide the design and establishment of more efficient electrocatalytic N2 reduction systems based on main group metal elements in the future. Keywords N2 reduction Main group Metal elements Challenges and strategies 1 Introduction Synthetic ammonia is one of the most significant fundamental industries in the present society for the substantial use of ammonia as the feedstock in the fields of fertilizer, plastic, textile, and pharmaceutical industries, as well as carbon-free energy conversion [1–4]. Over the past century, industrial-scale synthesis of ammonia is primarily relied on the traditional Haber-Bosch process, which requires rigorous operating conditions (300–550 °C, 200–300 atm) and high purity hydrogen and nitrogen gases as reactants, leading to rapid consumption of fossil energy and resulting in extensive greenhouse-gas emission [5–7]. Therefore, it is well worth developing an energy-efficient, environmentally benign, and highly efficient process for sustainable and large-scale ammonia production under ambient conditions. At present, artificial ammonia production under ambient conditions, including electrochemical ammonia production [8] photochemical ammonia production [9], plasma ammonia production [10], photo(electron) ammonia production [11], homogeneous and nitrogenase ammonia production [12], etc., have gained much attention due to the reducing of the fossil fuel consumption and the greenhouse-gas emission. However, the very low utilization rate and the uncertainty of solar energy restrict the utilization of photochemical ammonia production, the instability of nitrogenase and the complex process conditions make the nitrogenase ammonia production unsuitable for industrialization [13]. Compared with other processes, the electrochemical process is an attractive candidate for ammonia production due to the advantages of alternative proton sources, renewable energy supplies, mild reaction conditions and simplified reaction systems. However, the application of electrochemical synthetic ammonia in industrial production is still seriously hampered by the inefficient Faraday efficiency (FE) and the low NH3 yield caused by the sluggish cleave of the N≡N triple bond, the extremely week N2 adsorption and the low solubility of N2 in aqueous media [14]. The pivotal point in boosting electrochemical ammonia production performance is to exploit high-efficiency electrocatalysts. Recently, numerous nano-electrocatalysts, such as noble-metal-based catalysts (Au [15], Ru [16], Pd [17], Pt [18], etc.), transition metal-based catalysts (Fe [19], Co [20], Cu [21], Mo [22,23], Ti [24], V [25] etc.), main group metal-based catalysts (Bi [26], Sn [27], Li [28], Al [29], etc.) and metal-free catalysts (carbon-based [30] phosphorus-based [31], etc.), have been used for electrochemical synthesis of ammonia. Despite substantial progress that has been made, most of them are still far behind the scaled-up application requirement due to their high cost, long-term instability, especially the poor electrochemical performance caused by their favor competitive adsorption of H+ over N2. In the past three years, main group metal-based catalysts have played a significant role in the electrochemical ammonia production and exhibited preferable electrochemical performance due to their advantages of the strong interaction between the main group metal catalyst center and the N atom, low cost, abundant reserves and adjustable electronic structure [32–36]. In electrochemical ammonia production, main group elements not only can be directly served as catalysts to validly inhibit the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process but also act as electrolytes to promote electrochemical ammonia production. Previous reviews on electrochemical ammonia production electrocatalysts are mainly concentrated on the noble-metal-based catalysts [11,37–40], transition metal-based catalysts [41–43] and metal-free catalysts [44–46]. Though various main group metal-based catalysts, such as Li [28] Al [29], Sn [47], SnS2 [48], SnO2 [49], Bi [50], Bi2O3 [51], have broad application prospects in ammonia synthesis, a comprehensive review of the main group metal-based catalysts towards electrochemical ammonia production is still lacking, which is significant to boost their future development in this field. Herein, we provided an up-to-date comprehensive review of main group metal-based nitrogen fixation materials, in which we classify these electrocatalysts according to their main group and systematically discuss the role, mechanism and effect of each main group elements in electrochemical ammonia production. The understanding of their catalytic mechanisms can guide the design and establishment of more efficient electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis systems (See Fig. 1 ). 2 Fundamentals of N2 reduction 2.1 Reaction pathways During the electrochemical ammonia production process which is conducted in an aqueous electrolyte, nitrogen source is provided by the N2 molecules from the air; protons are supplied by electrolysis of water and transferred to the surface of the electrocatalysts by an applied voltage under ambient conditions [52]. This process is generally conducted in a three-electrode system in a double cell which is isolated by a proton exchange membrane. The primary anodic reaction and the cathodic reaction are the oxygen evolution reaction and the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), respectively, and both the two reactions depend on the pH of the electrolyte. Under acidic conditions, the protons are formed on the counter electrode passing directly through a proton exchange membrane to the cathode, where ammonia is produced. Thus, the two half-reactions are represented as the equation (1) and (2): (1) Anodic reaction: 3 H2O → 3/2 O2 + 6H+ + 6 e- (2) Cathodic reaction: N2 + 6H+ + 6 e- → 2 NH3 The reaction process under alkaline conditions or basic conditions is different from that of the acidic conditions, where N2 molecules in the cathode are directly combined with water and electrons to form ammonia [53]. The OH– ions, produced on the working electrode, are transported through an anion exchange membrane to the cathode and oxidized to form O2, described as equations (3) and (4): (3) Anodic reaction: 6 OH– → 3 H2O + 3/2 O2 + 6 e- (4) Cathodic reaction: N2 + 6 H2O + 6 e- → 2NH3 + 6 OH– The overall reaction, in either case, is shown below: (5) N2 + 3 H2O → 2 NH3 + 3/2 O2 The mechanism of the electrochemical ammonia production process is so complicated that it hasn’t been completely understood. The pathways of the ammonia production process are crucial for the reaction mechanism exploration, which are also vital to the realization of electrochemical ammonia production. Generally, two mechanisms, including the associative and the dissociative mechanism are recognized in this field [54–56]. The detailed reaction pathways for the NRR depend on the adsorption configurations of N2 molecules. When N2 is adsorbed by adopting the end-on pattern, as shown in Fig. 2 , the NRR will occur through the distal and alternating pathways. On the other hand, when N2 is adsorbed by the side-on pattern, the NRR will occur through the enzymatic and consecutive pathways (Fig. 2, red line and purple line) [38]. The dissociative pathway (Fig. 2, yellow line) is generally considered to occur in the Haber-Bosch process. Before the hydrogenation reaction, N≡N triple bonds of the adsorbed N2 molecules cleave, leaving N atoms on the catalyst surface, then the N atoms take part in further hydrogenation to form ammonia [57]. However, this dissociative pathway is impossible for ambient-condition electrochemical ammonia production due to a large amount of energy. The associative alternating pathway (Fig. 2, green line) manifests that the two nitrogen centers in the adsorbed N2 molecules are protonated until the last N-N bond dissociation [58]. Namely, the first ammonia is formed along with the last N-N bond cleavage, and the other ammonia is generated by successive addition of protons. For the associative distal pathway (Fig. 2, blue line), the first ammonia is obtained by consecutive hydrogenation occurring preferentially at the N atoms far from the catalyst, then the other ammonia is produced by the successive addition of protons generating on the surface of the catalyst that adsorbs N atom. The alternating pathway and distal pathway pathways, which belong to the associative mechanisms, are more preferable to occur in ambient-condition electrochemical ammonia production based on thermodynamics [59]. According to the above pathways, the ammonia synthesis processes on the surface of catalyst experiences two key steps, the first one is the adsorption of N2 molecular at the active sites to form the N2H∗ (∗indicates the active sites), the second one is the desorption of NH2 ∗ from the active sites to form the NH3. The main group metal elements, such as Bi, can reduce N2 to ammonia through alternating pathway or distal pathway pathways, and the potential-determining step (PDS) of NRR process catalyzed by Bi-based catalysts is usually the addition of the first hydrogen to ∗ N2 (∗N2 → N2H ∗ ). It can offer a lower free-energy change for the PDS, resulting in better NRR activity than some typical transition-metal catalysts due to the intense interaction between the Bi 6p band and the N 2p orbitals, and the limited surface electron accessible for HER [42,60]. Sn as another important main group metal element, its compounds can achieve satisfactory catalytic performances toward N2 fixation due to the similar reason as that of Bi element [61]. 2.2 Reaction potential In fact, a few reports have discussed the equilibrium potential of NRR. At present, there are two methods of calculation [62,63], where the standard potential for the half-reaction of N2 reduction to NH4OH is calculated according to the standard molar Gibbs energy of formation at 298.15 K and the equilibrium potential is calculated using the Nernst equation, assuming 1 atm of N2 and an NH4OH concentration of 0.01 mM in the solution, specific as follows: (i) N2(g) + 2H2O + 6H+ + 6e- = 2NH4OH (6) Δ G ° = - 33.8 kJ mol - 1 E° = −ΔG° / nF = 0.058 V, where n = 6 is the number of electrons transferred in the reaction and F is the Faraday constant. (7) E = E ° - RT / 6 F × ln NH 4 OH 2 / H + 6 + 0.059 V × pH = 0.156 V vs . RHE (ii) In this half-reaction of N2 reduction, the standard potential for this half reaction of NRR was 0.092 V. (8) E = E ° - RT / 6 F × ln NH 4 OH 2 / H + 6 + 0.059 V × pH = 0.191 V vs . RHE Actually, the standard equilibrium potential is calculated from standard molar Gibbs free energy of formation (Δf G° (NH3, g) = −16.7 kJ mol−1, Δf G° (NH3, l) = −26.5 kJ mol−1). We think that the standard equilibrium potential is more reasonable to be 0.092 V, because NH3 easily binds to water molecules. If NH3 is regarded as a gas, the Gibbs free energy will change when NH3(g) becomes NH3H2O. At the same time, the standard potential required for NRR (0.092 V vs. RHE) is very close to that of the HER (0 V vs. RHE). Therefore, one big challenge for electrochemical ammonia production is to suppress competitive HER. Using electrocatalysts with inert HER activity could be a feasible strategy to improve the performance of electrochemical ammonia production with better Faraday efficiency. The state-of-the-art strategy is segregating N2 reduction from the protonation of NH3 by a stepwise approach that effectively avoids the HER [64]. 2.3 Challenges of N2 reduction Recently, though great development has been achieved in electrochemical ammonia production in aqueous media under ambient conditions, its practical application is still severely restricted by the poor ammonia yields and low Faraday efficiency [65,66]. The key factors limiting the electrochemical catalysis performance are as follows: (i) The FE is mainly suppressed by the major side reaction called HER due to the very little overpotential [67]. (ii) The N2 molecule is chemically adsorbed on the active site, and electrons are obtained from the catalyst for activation. This process is viewed as the prerequisite step of NRR [68]. Owing to N≡N triple bonds has a high dissociation energy (941 kJ/mol) and N2 has a relatively low proton affinity, it is tough to adsorb and activate N2 molecules on the catalyst, thereby limiting the electrochemical performance of ammonia production [69]. (iii) The slight solubility of N2 in aqueous electrolytes significantly affects electrocatalytic performance due to the poor N2 mass transfer. Enlarging the surface area of the catalyst or increasing the solubility of N2 in the electrolyte can effectively promote the mass transfer, thereby boosting the rate of ammonia production. (iv) The quantification of NH3 is the key step to determine the catalyst performance. At present, the ammonia detection methods main include spectrophotometry, ion-selective electrode detection, ion chromatography and isotope method [70]. The main spectrophotometric methods are the indophenol blue method and Nessler’s reagent method, which are extensively applied in ammonia detection due to their excellent sensitivity and low cost. Compared to these two methods, the indophenol blue method is superior in lower detection limit (10 × 10−6 mol L-1) with better color rendering and preferable reproducibility. While the Nessler reagent method is competitive in terms of saving time and reducing reagent consumption, but failed in environmental protection for its color reagent containing mercury. However, certain metal ions dissolved in solution may interfere with the measurement. It is suggested to carry out a control experiment to eliminate interference [71]. The ion-selective electrode method is simple, fast, and has a wide detection range (0.01–17000 ppm). However, temperature and stirring speed should be controlled during the experiment. Ion chromatography has a low detection limit (3 × 10−7 mol L−1) with prominent reproducibility and accuracy. However, electrolytes containing Li+ and Na+ are inappropriate for use because the retention time is short, and organic electrolytes are also inapplicable [70]. In addition, 15N2 isotope experiments are needed to determine the source of ammonia, particularly the nitrogen-containing NRR catalyst. It is recommended to use at least two detection methods to determine the number of products, making the results more convincing [42]. 2.4 Unique superiority of main group elements Previous theoretical calculations and experimental studies have predicted that transition metals (TMs), such as Mo, Fe and Ti can strongly interact with N2 through N-metal bonds because they combine the vacant and occupied d orbitals, where an “acceptance-donation” path for electronic transfer can be formed, thus weakening the N≡N triple bond (Fig. 3 a) [72,73]. The vacant d orbitals of TM accept the lone-pair electrons of N2, the occupied d orbitals of TM provide electrons to the π* antibonding orbitals (Fig. 3b) [74]. Similar to TM, some main group metal elements, such as Ga and Bi have the empty and occupied orbitals concurrently for the formation of the “acceptance-donation” pathway [75]. Ga (4s 24p 1) takes sp 3 hybridization, remaining three individually occupied orbitals and one vacant orbital. The Bi 6p band supplies electrons for the π* antibonding orbitals that adsorb N2, achieving effective nitrogen activation [76]. It is demonstrated that various Bi-based catalysts, including Bi nanoparticles and bismuth oxides, have superior nitrogen reduction performance. Meanwhile, the main group of metallic elements, such as Al, Sb, Sn and their compounds can effectively increase the densities of exposed active sites by introducing specific porous structures, vacancies and defects, active crystal planes, or hybrid material interface, etc., thus enhance the catalytic activity by weakening the bond of N≡N and lower the energy of N2 reduction. For alkali metals, it is shown that Li+ and K+ can effectively inhibit HER when they are used as the electrolyte in experiments, but the specific reaction mechanism remains to be further proved. View from these points, main group elements-based catalysts have many advantages, including the intrinsic less reactive nature of HER, special electronic structure to adsorption and activation of N2, etc., which are devoted to overcoming the above limiting factors and considered as promising candidates to promote electrochemical ammonia production. 3 Main group metal element-based catalysts 3.1 Alkali metal group The lithium and potassium of alkali metals are significant in the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction due to the unique properties, which can effectively circumvent the HER, resulting in improving the Faraday efficiency and selectivity. Alkali metals are used in NRR mainly include (i) lithium mediated method, (ii) electrolyte, and (iii) directly as the catalyst. (i) Lithium mediated method The lithium-mediated method has the characteristics of high rate and high Faraday efficiency for NRR because metallic Li can activate N2 to form lithium nitride (Li3N) at ambient conditions due to its strong reducing power [77]. In 1993, this “Li mediated pathway” was first used for electrochemical ammonia production by Tsuneto et al. [78], and exhibited an impressively excellent FE as high as 57.7%, when the experiment carried out on the iron electrode with 0.18 M ethanol as the proton source and tetrahydrofuran (THF) as the electrolyte at 5.07 MPa [79]. However, this reaction can only take place under high pressure and non-water-derived electron donors. Inspired by such “Li mediated pathway” strategy, in 2017, Ma et al. [80] introduced rechargeable lithium-nitrogen (Li-N2) batteries for electrochemical ammonia fixation process, which increased the FE to 59% and decreased the energy consumption under ambient conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), this Li-N2 battery comprises a Li anode, a carbon cloth cathode, an ether-based electrolyte (1 M LiCF3SO3 in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether, TEGDME) and a glass fiber separator. During the discharge process of the rechargeable Li-N2 battery, Li3N intermediates are formed by the combination of Li+ ions and N2 molecules and are decomposed into Li and N2 on the charging process. Though there are still some side reactions (such as cathode and/or electrolyte decomposition during the charging process) and the cycle life of the Li-N2 battery is limited for both the charge and discharge potentials undergo deviations in the original 40 cycles, as shown in Fig. 4(b, c), this promising proof-of-concept research not only provides a prospective candidate for reversible N2 fixation processes but also offers a progressive Li/Li3N cycle for new-generation electrochemical energy-storage systems. Meanwhile, there is a key technical problem for Li-N2 battery in the way of synthetic ammonia production, which is how to ensure the Li3N intermediates react with water to produce ammonia without affecting the battery’s charge and discharge cycle. McEnaney et al. [81] proposed a novel and sustainable electrochemical ammonia production strategy with a stepwise lithium cycling process, which exhibited an all-time high current efficiency of 88.5% and unprecedented selectivity for ammonia production at atmospheric pressure in aqueous. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the process has three steps: molten salt electrolysis of LiOH, direct nitridation of Li with N2 and the exothermic release of NH3 from Li3N, reproducing the LiOH and completing the cycle. This ultrahigh electrocatalytic performance is to separate the subsequent protonated N2 into NH3 in the reduction process through a stepwise method, effectively avoiding the HER process. It is demonstrated by density functional theory calculations (DFT) and the insights of the diffusion energy barrier, which Li-based materials are the best candidate for this process, as presented in Fig. 4(e, f). However, it is difficult to separate the liquid lithium from the molten salt at the high temperature in the process of molten salt electrolysis, which makes the metal lithium become liquid. To solve this problem, Kim et al. [82] employed reactive surface for Li deposited on a Ni substrate and Li-ion conducting glass ceramic material (LISICON) as the proton exchange membrane. It proposed a novel Li-mediated three-step ammonia production process. As shown in Fig. 4(g), a hybrid aqueous/LISICON/organic electrolytic cell was used to deposit Li on the Ni substrate. Then Li3N was formed by the nitridation of the deposited Li in an N2 atmosphere. Finally, the formed Li3N was immersed in dilute sulfuric acid for hydrolysis to produce NH4 +. This original three-step ammonia synthesis approach can achieve a considerable efficiency with the maximum FE of 52.3%. However, temperatures above 220 ℃ are still necessary in the processes of Li deposition and nitridation to avoid the Li-consuming side reactions, such as the reaction between Li and electrolyte, which prevents the nitridation of Li. Subsequently, their group [83] found that adding cesium salt in a conventional organic electrolyte can enhance the lithium plating performance, which plays a decisive role in improving Faradic efficiency. According to their work, the simple addition of cesium perchlorate (0.03 M CsClO4) into the organic catholyte of a Li-plating cell successfully raised the FE of ammonia production to 82.3% under similar experimental conditions as the previous work [82]. This significant improvement is mainly due to the morphology of Li deposits caused by Cs, which supplies the interfacial side reactions between metallic Li and propylene carbonate. As shown in Fig. 4(h), the morphologies of Li deposits in the presence of CsClO4 are cylindric, lengthened structures with the thicker diameter and much smoother surface than that of no additive which reduces the interfacial area with side reactions. The Lithium-mediated method is a promising ammonia production approach with absolute superiority FE for the effective inhibition of HER. The Lithium-mediated method is another way to activate N2 at room temperature and pressure. This method avoids the competition between the activation process and the hydrogenation process, obtaining higher NH3 yield and FE, but it requires a high temperature in the complicated process. In the future, the high efficiency nitrogen fixation can be realized by improving the lithium plating process and reducing the side reaction of lithium for its further use in industrial ammonia production. The development of stable electrode materials and electrolytes, as well as studying the complex mechanism of the Li-N2 battery, and improving their catalytic performance are the focus of Li-N2 battery research. (ii) Electrolyte The nitrogen reduction reaction is restrained by the dominant competing HER for the standard potential required for the NRR, which is very close to that of the HER in the aqueous electrolyte. In recent years, more and more researches on electrochemical ammonia production select Li+ or K+ ion-containing electrolyte to restrict the HER, and indeed get a favorable FE and ammonia yield rate. The excellent performance has been due to the strong interaction between Li+ ion or K+ ion and N2, as well as the steric effect of Li+ ions [84–93] or K+ ion. Lithium-ion plays an irreplaceable role as electrolytes in boosting the selectivity of electrochemical ammonia production in the aqueous electrolyte under ambient conditions, especially when it reacts with catalyst atoms to form a new kind of Li+ mediate active site. A Li+ incorporation strategy to restrict HER and provide reaction sites for the NRR was reported by Wang and co-workers [94]. In their work, a Li+-incorporated poly (N-ethyl-benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic diimide) (PEBCD) was used as an electrocatalyst for ammonia production, dramatically increasing the NRR activity in 0.5 M Li2SO4 electrolyte, with the FE of 2.58% at −0.4 V (vs. RHE) and NH3 yield rate of 9.3 × 10−4 mol h−1 m−2. In the PEBCD matrix, studies had indicated that the combination of Li+ and O could inhibit the HER and promote nitrogen adsorption. This [O-Li+] active site could also provide a high potential range for NRR in the “[O-Li+] • N2-Hx ” alternate hydrogenation mode (Fig. 5 a). Based on the above Li+ incorporation strategy, MoS2 nanosheets (Fig. 5b), a kind of typical HER electrocatalysts, could improve NRR catalytic activity and selectivity through Li-S interactions [32]. When 0.1 M Li2SO4 was used as the electrolyte, S-rich MoS2 nanosheets exhibited superior NRR performance with the FE of 9.81% and NH3 yield rate of 43.4 μg h−1 mg−2 MoS2 at −0.2 V (vs RHE). MoS2 nanosheets were superior to the same catalyst in the absence of Li+ ions owing to the strong Li-S interactions. Theoretical calculations indicated that S-edge sites of MoS2 can strongly combine with Li+ in the electrolyte to form “Li-S” interactions, which could effectively inhibit the HER catalytic performance of MoS2 through reducing H* adsorption free energy, as well as improve the NRR selectivity and activity by enhancing the N2 adsorption free energy and resulting in a lower activation energy barrier for the NRR (Fig. 5c). Zhang et al. [95] employed Nano-Fe decorated carbon cloth as the cathode and 1 M K3PO4 as the electrolyte for NRR. The optimized ammonia yield rate was 79.0 ± 5 × 10−11 mol s−1 cm−2 with the FE of 16.68%. It was found that phosphorus and potassium synergistically promoted the NRR process, where K+ could effectively prevent H+ adsorbed on the catalyst surface activation sites for inhibiting the HER, and PO4 3- can increase the solubility of N2 in water for promoting nitrogen to produce ammonia. (iii) Directly as catalyst It is also a feasible strategy that is liberating Li+ ions from electrolytes by incorporating Li+ ions into some metallic oxide or salts to form solid catalysts. Spinel LiMn2O4 nanofibers were obtained by adding Li+ ions into Mn3O4 to (Fig. 5d) and used for NRR catalysts [28]. This noble-metal-free electrocatalyst exhibited excellent performance and outstanding stability towards NRR with a superior FE of 7.44% at −0.50 V (vs RHE) in 0.1 M HCl (Fig. 5e), which was far higher than that for the Mn3O4 nanocube (3.0%) [96] under the similar experimental conditions. When lithium and potassium are used in electrolytes, Li+ and K+ can inhibit the HER. Li+ can be combined with the active site of hydrogen production to inhibit the HER. K+ suppresses the HER by preventing the adsorption of H+ on the active-site at the catalyst surface. Therefore, future studies can improve the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction performance by adjusting the electrolyte or adding ions for inhibiting the HER into the catalysts. At present, there are few studies on the direct use of alkali metals as catalysts. Future research can consider adding alkali metal ions directly to the catalyst, which may further improve the nitrogen reduction performance. 3.2 Boron group Among boron group metal elements, aluminum (Al) and gallium (Ga) have been used for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction as so far [36,97]. Al possesses unparalleled advantages such as abundant reserves, high specific energy, low cost, safety for transportation, storage and stability. It has been widely concerned in the fields of batteries, capacitors and electrocatalysis. Al-based electrocatalysts have been used in electrochemical ammonia production, for instance, metallic aluminum (Al), transition mental aluminum boride (MoAlB single crystals), molecular aluminum complex and urchin-like Al-doped Co3O4 (Al-Co3O4/NF). Ga is a mysterious liquid metal with a low melting point and high boiling point. At present, gallium compounds are regarded as semiconductor materials with excellent performance and have been extensive applied to optoelectronics industry and microwave communication industry. Although theoretical calculations show that Ga has many essential advantages for electrochemical ammonia production, its applications in this field are still in infancy. Inspired by biological N2 fixation and transformation at the polymetallic active sites of nitrogenase, coordination complexes composed of metal atoms and organic ligands are used as ammonia production catalysts. Berben and co-workers [98] had made substantial progress in electrochemical N2 fixation by employing aluminum (III) coordination complex as the catalyst. According to the report, when aluminum (III) coordination complex was used as the catalyst, electrochemical ammonia production was realized with FE of 21 ± 3% in 0.3 M Bu4NPF6 THF electrolyte containing 6 mM 4-dimethylaminopyridinum (DMAPH+) at −1.16 V (vs. SCE) under 1 atm N2. The reactivity of the molecular Al complex and its possible participation in the NRR was discussed. However, no experimental data have indicated that N2 interacts with Al up to now. They hypothesized that the hydride was transferred from the ligand backbone to N2. Therefore, the mechanism of the molecular Al complexes for NRR has not been investigated yet. But this work opens up a novel method for main group metal elements used in electrochemical ammonia production. Rechargeable metal-gas batteries have double efficacy of energy conversion and gas utilization. Up to now, rechargeable Li-N2 battery has been widely used in nitrogen fixation and exhibited ultrahigh FE with the help of a step-wise strategy. Unfortunately, the Li-N2 battery still suffers from large energy input and instability of lithium metal. Recently, Zhi’s group [99] figured out that the spontaneity of the reaction 2Al (s) + N2 (g) = 2AlN (s) was much higher than that of the reaction 6Li (s) + N2 (g) = 2Li3N (s) because ΔG (AlN) was much more negative than ΔG (Li3N) (Fig. 6 a). An Al-N2 battery was proposed and demonstrated by a system composed of an ionic liquid electrolyte (AlCl/1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride), graphene-supported Pd (graphene/Pd) cathode and Al anode. This system could realize the excellent N2 fixation by the production of AlN with the impressive FE of 51.2%, and simultaneously accomplish effective energy storage (Fig. 6b, c). Then AlN immediately reacted with NaOH to form NH3, getting a striking ammonia yield of 27.1 mg/gcat·h−1 according to the equation AlN + NaOH + 2H2O = NaAlO2 + NH3·H2O. Based on their results, they predicted that the configuration of Al-N2 battery with chloroaluminate-based ionic liquid was illustrated in Fig. 6(d). In the Al-N2 battery, Al2Cl7 - ions transferred from anode to cathode and subsequently combined with N2 to form AlN, which was decomposed into N2 and Al2Cl7 - upon the charging process. Recently, urchin-like Al-doped Co3O4 nanospheres with rich oxygen vacancies decorated on the three-dimensional (3D) Ni foam were prepared by hydrothermal method and annealing treatment (Al-Co3O4/NF) [36]. Through comparing the atomic ratio of Co2+ and Co3+ (Fig. 6e), the authors declared that Al doping played a crucial part in increasing oxygen vacancies (Ovs), which provided unsaturated coordination sites for enhancing the chemical adsorption of N2 molecules and adjusting electronic properties of Co3O4, thereby promoting nitrogen reduction activity. What’s more interesting is that the urchin-like nanostructure of Al-Co3O4/NF could restrict the combination of bubbles to expose more active sites for nitrogen adsorption, which suppressed the HER on the surface of Al-Co3O4/NF. The NRR mechanism was reasonably monitored by the electrochemical in situ Fourier transform infrared (in situ-FTIR) spectroscopy (Fig. 6f), and the results showed that the nitrogen reduction process of Al-Co3O4 catalyst was carried out by an associated alternate pathway. Recently, our group [29] firstly used molybdenum aluminum boride single crystals (MoAlB SCs) as electrocatalysts to take advantage of its layered structure and the characteristics of the main group elements for establishing a more efficient electrochemical ammonia production system. The layered ternary borides MoAlB SCs displayed excellent electrocatalytic performances with the FE of 30.1% and NH3 yield of 9.2 µg h−1 cm−2 mg-1 cat at the ultralow overpotential (-0.05 V vs. RHE), which was closed to the theory potential in 0.1 M KOH solution. Through further mechanism studies, we found that the introduction of main group elements Al and B could enhance the selective affinity to N2 because of the strong interactions between the Al 3p/B 2p band and the N 2p orbitals, while Mo atoms exhibited superior catalytic performance towards the following N2 reduction. The “multicomponent” MAB phase could provide multiple active sites for N2 adsorption, as well as a high specific surface for providing more active sites for N2 reduction (Fig. 6g). This work provided a promising candidate and catalyst design principles for the synthesis of ammonia. As a member of the boron group element, Ga has similar electronic properties as B element (Fig. 7 a), it can have both vacant and occupied orbitals. As shown in Fig. 7(b), Ga takes sp 3 hybridization, leaving three separately occupied orbitals and a vacant orbital. Therefore, it is worth studying whether Ga element has the catalytic activity of nitrogen fixation. The possibility of N2 adsorption and reduction on Ga atoms was first theoretically evaluated by Huang and co-workers [97]. They put forward that Ga element had potential application prospects in electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction by theoretical calculation when modulated by defect-size engineering properly. By using V-GaSe and Janus V-GaInSe2 as the model electrocatalysts, they proved that Ga atoms in V-GaSe exhibited a good N2 adsorption capacity and an excellent electrocatalytic performance because three sp 3-hybridized orbitals of Ga could capture N2 by the pulling effect. With the increase of tensile strain, the overlap of electron states between Ga and N decreased and moved towards Fermi energy level gradually, leading to a decrease of free energy. When In atoms were introduced into GaSe, the obtained Janus defective structured V-GaInSe2 had stronger N2 fixation ability and higher NRR performance than V-GaSe. It was contributed to the electron density of active Ga atoms was enhanced, and the vacancy size was enlarged. The onset potential on 4% strained V-GaInSe2 was calculated to be 0.31 V, which was comparable to that of the 8% strained V-GaSe (Fig. 7c,d). Besides, the free-energy change was below 0.52 eV for a much easier NH3 release. This computational study offered a new method for tuning the NRR performance by regulating the defect size and the electron density of the catalyst. Boron group metal-based materials has been proved to be attractive electrocatalysts towards synthesis of ammonia, presenting higher electrochemical selectivity and activity because of the interaction between the p orbital and N atom, which is prone to adsorb N2 molecular for better selectivity. The aluminum complex has been proven to own nitrogen reduction activity, but the specific reaction mechanism is still unclear, and the interaction between Al and N2 needs to be further confirmed. Al-N2 battery is much more energy-saving and easier to implement than Li-N2 battery. It will be more promising in this field if ammonia could be produced in this system. Moreover, some ingenious strategies have combined heteroatom-doping, substrate support and structural engineering to promote the performance of catalysts, providing a direction for high-efficient electrocatalyst designation. Theoretical calculations have shown that Ga element can capture N2 σ electrons by the stretching effect [97]. However, whether Ga can fix nitrogen still needs to be proved, combined with experiments. 3.3 Carbon group Tin (Sn), as an earth-abundant and inexpensive metal, has attracted extensive attentions as an electrocatalyst in the fields of electrocatalysis, lithium-ion battery and energy storage devices, because Sn-based materials have the characteristics of low cost, high activity and non-toxicity. At present, Sn-based materials are used in NRR mainly including amorphous Sn, dendritic Sn, two-dimensional SnS2 and semiconductor SnO2, as well as their composites with other species. Several strategies, such as heteroatom doping, vacancy engineering, amorphous phases and structural design, have been used on Sn-based materials for introducing more exposed active sites to obtain higher catalyst activity. SnS2-based materials currently show immense development prospects in the field of electrocatalysis because of the excellent catalytic performance, adjustable electronic structure and two-dimensional morphology [100]. However, their applications in the electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia are hindered by poor conductivity and difficult preparation of the fine structure with the best performance. Flower-like SnS2 (Fig. 8 a) was synthesized directly on the conductive substrate (Ni foam) by self-organized growth without any binder [101]. The obtained SnS2 @ Ni foam exhibited a FE of 10.8% and an NH3yield of 9.17 × 10-10 mol s−1 cm−2 at −0.5 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M Na2SO4 under ambient conditions, even better than those of Au sub-nanoclusters anchored on TiO2 (8.11% and 3.5 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2). No hydrazine byproduct was detected in the electrolyte demonstrating a good selectivity for ammonia production. Based on the comparison experiments, the authors claimed that the NRR activity of SnS2 was effectively enhanced by immobilizing well-organized, flower-like and two-dimensional nano SnS2 on 3D porous Ni foam, which could not only provide abundant active sites for nitrogen reduction but also make the electrolyte easily penetrate and effectively reduce the transport distance of protons and electrons. This work demonstrated the nitrogen reduction ability of SnS2 and provided a universal strategy for developing a series of excellent hybrid electrocatalysts. Previous research found that amorphous catalysts could reduce the energy barrier and induce defective sites to promote catalytic activity [102–104]. For example, amorphous Bi4V2O11 [105] and amorphous Au [106] could obtain an enhanced electrocatalytic NRR performance over their crystalline form. Motivated by these practical experiences, a in situ electrochemical reduction process to convert SnS2 into amorphous Sn (Fig. 8b) was adopted by Ye and co-workers [47], and the catalytic activity of the synthesized amorphous Sn/crystalline SnS2 (Sn/SnS2) was improved. According to the comparative electrochemical NRR tests with a series of Sn/SnS2 molar ratios, the amorphous Sn acting as the active component significantly improved the catalytic performance of nitrogen reduction. Benefit from the dendritic structure, Sun et al. [27] used metallic Sn dendrite ornamented on Sn foil (Sn D/SF) (Fig. 8c) for NRR. Sn D/SF had better NRR catalytic activity with a FE of 3.67% and an NH3 yield of 5.66 × 10−11 mol s−1 cm−2 at −0.6 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7) when compared with Sn foil and Sn NPs/SF. Through combining heteroatom doping and vacancy engineering strategies to regulate the electronic structure of SnS2 [48], Mo-doped SnS2 nanosheets (Fig. 8d) with abundant vacancies demonstrated a remarkably outstanding NRR performance with a FE of 20.8% (at −0.4 V vs. RHE) and an NH3 yield of 41.3 mg h−1 mg−1 (at −0.5 V vs. RHE) in 0.5 M LiClO4 electrolyte under ambient conditions. Mechanism study by DFT calculation showed that the S-vacancy (Vs) was generated due to Mo-doping, thus the nitrogen reduction activity of SnS2 was improved. The coexistence of Mo doping and Vs formed the Mo-Sn-Sn catalytic sites, which forcefully activated nitrogen and reduced the reaction energy barrier (Fig. 8e-g). SnO2, as an essential semiconductor, has been widely used as an electrocatalyst in the field of electrocatalysis CO2 reduction reaction [107,108], lithium-ion batteries [109,110], fuel cells and supercapacitors [111,112]. Sun et al. [113] for the first time demonstrated the feasibility of SnO2 for NRR potential applications by implanting cubic sub-micron SnO2 particles onto carbon cloth (CC) (Fig. 9 a). The obtained hybrid catalyst SnO2/CC achieved a relative high FE of 2.17% at −0.7 V (vs. RHE) and a large NH3 yield of 1.47 × 10-10 mol s−1 cm−2 at −0.8 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M Na2SO4 under ambient conditions. To enhance the active sites and the conductivity of SnO2 for a better NRR activity, SnO2 quantum dots (QDs) was selected as catalysts [33], which in situ grew on the surface of reduced graphene oxide (RGO). The as-synthesized SnO2 QDs/RGO delivered an inferior HER activity and a superior NRR activity with outstanding stability and selectivity. SnO2 QDs with the ultrasmall size exposed more active sites, meanwhile, the RGO enhanced the conductivity and reduced the self-aggregation of the SnO2 QDs. The tight coupling between SnO2 QDs and RGO further facilitated the charge transfer and lowered the energy barrier for quickstep (*N→*N2H) (Fig. 9b). An efficient NRR electrocatalyst by immobilizing fluorine (F)-doped SnO2 mesoporous nanosheets on carbon cloth (F-SnO2/CC) was exploited by a facile solvothermal approach [61]. Theoretical calculation by DFT manifested that F-doping was more beneficial to adjust the electronic structure of SnO2, enhance its conductivity and increase the active Sn phase, thus lowering the reaction energy barrier as well as improving the performance of NRR (Fig. 9c). Ding’s team [114] reported an efficient, double-active electrocatalyst for nitrogen fixation synthesized by stable confining black phosphorus quantum dots (BP QDs) on black tin oxide nanotubes. In the as-prepared BP @ SnO2-X, BP QDs could offer a large specific surface area and rich active sites, and SnO2-X not only had excellent conductivity and catalytic activity but also could effectively suppress the agglomeration of BP QDs and improve the stability of the structure. Their synergistic effect made BP @ SnO2-X has excellent catalytic nitrogen reduction activity and cycle stability. This double-active strategy is expected to design more cost-effective and better performance catalysts for nitrogen reduction. Huang’s team [115] electrochemically reduced N2 to NH3 through the vacancy engineering of core @ shell structured Au @ SnO2 nanoparticles (NPs) (Fig. 9d). They found that the ultrathin amorphous SnO2 shell with enriched oxygen vacancies was conducive to adsorb N2 and promote the N2 activation. Meanwhile, the metallic Au core made sure the good electrical conductivity for accelerating electrons transport during the electrochemical NRR, synergistically boosting the N2 electrochemical reduction. As confirmed by the 15N-labeling and controlled experiments, the core @ shell Au @ amorphous SnO2 NPs with abundant oxygen vacancies showed the best performance for N2 electrochemical reduction with a FE of 15.2% and an NH3 yield rate of 21.9 μg h−1 mgcat -1 at −0.2 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M HCl electrolyte, which surpassed the Au @ crystalline SnO2 NP. A new type of Janus electrocatalyst (Fe-SnO2) for bifunctional electrochemical nitrogen fixation was compounded by a hydrothermal reaction [49]. The Fe-SnO2 achieved a high NH3 yield of 82.7 µg h−1 mgcat. -1 and a FE of 20.4%, superior to all noble-metal-free electrocatalysts reported in the acid electrolyte. It obtained a prominent N2 oxidation reaction (NOR) electrocatalytic activity with a NO3 – yields of 42.9 µg h−1 mgcat. -1 and a FE of 0.84%. Utilizing experiments and DFT calculations, the authors revealed that the single atom Fe anchored by oxygen vacancy could effectively adsorb and activate N2, which effectively reduced N≡N fracture barrier for enhancing the nitrogen reduction performance. Therefore, the Fe anchored by oxygen vacancies should be the active center in Fe-SnO2 (Fig. 9e,f). For Sn-based materials, amorphous Sn is the active phase for N2 reduction. SnS2 itself has S vacancies, so we can consider using the S vacancies of SnS2 to enhance the nitrogen reduction performance of SnS2-based catalysts by the synergistic effect between molecules. As a semiconductor material, SnO2 itself has catalytic activity, but its NRR performance is low, which may be due to the low conductivity, limited active sites and poor adsorption. Therefore, the nitrogen reduction performance of Sn-based materials can be improved through atomic doping and vacancy engineering. 3.4 Pnicogen group Antimony (Sb) and Bismuth (Bi), as the two metal elements in the pnicogen group, have become the focused elements for scientists to develop nitrogen reduction catalysts, especially owing to the high free energy barrier for hydrogen adsorption and limited electron accessibility on their surface, which can effectively suppress the HER and play important roles in electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction. Sb-based materials have been used in the field of electrocatalysis because of their abundant reserves and excellent electrochemical reversibility. Bi is a semi-metal with a layered structure similar to black phosphorus [31]. When the metallic Bi is stripped into single-layer or multilayer nanosheets, it will be converted into a semiconductor. Since the surface of semiconductor Bi has weak adsorption of hydrogen, HER is suppressed, and NRR is improved. So far, Bi-based materials, for example, Bi nanoarrays [60], Bi nanoparticles [26], defect-Bi (110) nanoplates [35], dendritic Bi [50], mosaic Bi nanosheets [116], flower-like bismuth oxide [51], Bi4V2O11/CeO2 hybrid [105], vacancy-rich BiVO4 [117] and Bi2O3/FEG [118] have been explored for N2 fixation. (i) Sb-based catalysts Recently, Sb-based catalysts have achieved high catalytic activity and selectivity at low reductive potential, which is unmatched to any other nitrogen reduction catalysts. Cho and coworkers [34] reported a strategy for boosting the FE of NRR by loading Sb-based composites (SbPO4) on phosphorous-doped carbon (PC), leading to a record high FE of 34% for ammonia production even at the ultralow reductive potential of −0.1 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte under mild conditions. The nanocomposite of PC/Sb/SbPO4 also exhibited a high FE of 31% at −0.15 V (vs. RHE) and an excellent ammonia yield rate of 25 μg h−1 mgcat -1 at −0.25 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 HCl under mild conditions. According to their ex-situ electrochemical study, both SbPO4 and PC acted as active sites that enhanced its NRR performance. Although Sb0 was coated with SbPO4 on the surface, it was not directly involved in NRR but beneficial to increase the exposure of the SbPO4 active sites. PC substrate could effectively prevent the aggregation of Sb/SbPO4 particles and improve structural stability. Furthermore, heteroatom P doping into carbon effectively tailored its electron structure, significantly improving the conductivity of the nanocomposite. Based on the synergistic effect of the components, the catalyst had excellent activity towards NRR. The novel surface-rough Rh2Sb nanorods (RNRs) with high-index facets were synthesized by Huang et al. [119] for the first time. It was demonstrated that surface regulation was significant to promote NRR performance. The Rh2Sb RNRs/C showed a high NH3 yield rate of 222.85 ± 12.96 mg h−1 mgRh -1 at −0.45 V (vs. RHE), far more than those of the Rh2Sb SNRs/C and Rh nanoparticles owing to the enhanced adsorption and activation of N2 on the high-index facets of Rh2Sb RNRs/C. This Rh2Sb RNRs/C exhibited durable stability even after 10 h of continuous electrolysis. Our group [120] was involved in the development of few-layer antimonene (FL-Sb) nanosheets. Theoretical calculations suggested that Sb2O3 acted as the active sites for the NRR process due to the increased polarity. It obtained a maximum NH3 yield of 180.39 mg h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.1 V (vs. RHE) with FE of 5.8%. The optimal FE for FL-Sb was 11.6% at + 0.05 V (vs. RHE) with NH3 yield of 133.1 mg h−1 mgcat -1. These NH3 yields and FEs obtained for the 2D FL-Sb were comparable most advanced electrocatalysts including some noble metal-based catalysts. (ii) Bi-based catalysts Among the various reported NRR electrocatalysts, such as noble metals [121,122], transition metal compounds [84,123], heteroatom-doped carbon [124] and single-atom catalysts [125], Bi-based materials have become the focus of NRR research because of their unique electronic structures [42,76,126]. Previous reports have shown that the 6p band of Bi can provide localized electrons for back-donation to the π* antibonding orbitals of adsorbed N2 molecules, enabling efficient activation and reduction [41]. In previous studies, bismuth-based materials were mainly used in electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction and photocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction, presenting excellent reactivity. Sun and coworkers [60] experimentally described the activity towards NRR by arranging Bi nanosheets on copper foil (Bi NS/CF). Theoretical calculations showed that the reaction occurred on the Bi (012) crystal plane (Fig. 10 a). Their team [50] also proved that the abundant-oriented sharp tips provided by the dendritic structure of Bi nanodendrites (Bi NDs) (Fig. 10b) also had nitrogen reduction activity with excellent selectivity. When tested in 0.1 M HCl, they afforded a large NH3 yield of 25.86 mg h−1 mgcat -1 and a high FE of 10.8% at −0.60 V (vs. RHE) and −0.55 V (vs. RHE), respectively. Bi dendrites would be used as a starting material for the design and development of hybrid catalysts towards N2 reduction applications in further research. Yan et al. [42] reported that both bismuth nanocrystals (Bi NCs) and potassium cations (K+) simultaneously contributed to the NRR process. Their calculation results showed that the Bi surface binding strongly to *NNH, inert to HER. K+ ions could promote the NRR process by inhibiting protons transfer for HER (Fig. 10c). The authors claimed that Bi could offer a lower free-energy change (ΔG) for the potential-determining step (PDS), thus exhibited a preferable intrinsic NRR activity than Au. Meanwhile, K+ could further reduce the ΔG required by that of PDS and manipulate the diffusion process of protons to make it more selective for N2 reduction. Consequently, the Bi–K+ pair could promote the NRR to obtain a record-breaking FE (66%) and with an ammonia yield of 200 mmol NH3 g-1h−1 in high concentration K+ solutions. A two-dimensional mosaic bismuth nanosheet (Bi NS) [116] was obtained by in situ electrochemical reduction process (Fig. 10d). The Bi NS structure could provide edge Bi atoms with delocalized p electrons as active sites, which could efficiently adsorb and reduce N2 and exhibit favorable average ammonia yield 2.54 ± 0.16 μgNH3 cm-2h−1 with a FE of 10.46 ± 1.45% at −0.8 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M Na2SO4. However, the determination of the active sites and the reaction mechanism were still unclear owing to the structural and chemical changes of Bi at reaction potentials. Therefore, some in situ characterization techniques and on-line monitoring methods, such as in situ Raman, in situ electron microscopy and online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry were employed [26] to monitor and optimize the electronic and geometric structures of bismuth active species in densely contacted Bi0 nanoparticles, as well as detect the production of NH3 and N2H2 during NRR process, revealing a possible pathway through two-step reduction and decomposition (Fig. 10e). Yan and his colleagues [35] prepared defect-rich Bi (110) nanoplates as NRR catalyst from Bi2O3 nanoplates by low-temperature plasma bombardment (Fig. 10f). The quantitative detection of catalytic products in aqueous electrolytes was measured by 1H NMR measurements with 15N2 or 14N2 gas for the first time. It was found that Bi (110) nanoplates with abundant isolated Bi vacancies showed a high FE of 11.68% at −0.6 V (vs RHE) and a 15NH3 production rate of 5.453 mg mgBi -1h−1 at −0.9 V (vs RHE). 2D Bi nanosheets could afford more intrinsic energetic edge sites than Bi nanoparticles, so it was easier to adsorb and active N2 molecules. Therefore, single crystallinity bismuth (Bi) nanosheets [127] exhibited better NRR performance than its corresponding nanoparticles, achieving an NH3 yield of 12.49 μg h−1 mgcat -1 with a high FE of 7.09%. DFT calculations further supported this conclusion by proving that the exposed edge sites were conducive to the adsorption and activation of N2 molecules. These Bi nanosheets were obtained through an in situ electrocatalytic topotactic transformation method by using bismuth iodide oxide nanosheets as raw material, avoiding the long duration ultrasonic treatment in the exfoliation process of nanosheets (Fig. 10g). This is the first time that topotactic transformation method has been used as an efficient catalyst preparation method in the preparation of NRR catalysts. Oxygen vacancies (OVs), which can effectively lower the energy barrier by regulating the reaction pathways, are of particular significance for inert gas molecules adsorption and activation [128]. It is reported that O2, CO2 and N2 molecules could be activated to their high-energy intermediates by OVs [129,130]. Semiconductors fabricated with well-designed OVs can break the kinetic limitation for a better N2 adsorption and NRR activity. Amorphous catalysts are widely used in many electrocatalysis applications because of their rich defect sites and reduced energy barriers [104,131]. Benefitting from the high density of defective sites and the reduced energy barrier in amorphous catalysts, remarkable performance has been realized in various electrocatalytic applications [132,133]. Inspired by the importance of OVs for electrocatalysis, bismuth vanadate (Bi4V2O11) based materials with abundant oxygen vacancies have great potential as competent NRR catalysts [134,135]. Chen et al. [105] found that Bi4V2O11/CeO2 amorphous phase (BVC-A) had better NRR performance than Bi4V2O11/CeO2 crystalline phase (BVC-C). Amorphous Bi4V2O11 contained a large number of defects that acted as active centers. CeO2 could induce the transformation of the amorphous structure (Fig. 11 a) and promote the interface charge transfer. By modulating the initial pH values of the reaction mixture, BiVO4 with various levels of OVs had been successfully synthesized via the hydrothermal method (Fig. 11b) [117]. According to their electrocatalytic results, the BiVO4 synthesized at the initial pH of 7 possessed the highest OVs and exhibited excellent NRR performances with an NH3 yield rate of 8.60 µg h−1 mgcat. −1 and a FE of 10.04% at −0.5 V (vs. RHE). In addition, it had excellent stability up to 24 h continuous electrocatalysis. This excellent catalytic performance came from the introduction of OVs, which enhanced N2 adsorption energy and afforded a more favorable active reaction site at the V atom. The successful application of this non-precious metal NRR catalyst opens a new chapter of transition metal vanadium and its compounds as low-cost NRR electrocatalysts, especially for practical applications. Bismuth-based materials have become a kind of attractive catalysts in the field of catalysis, especially electrocatalytic CO2 reduction and photocatalytic N2 reduction [136–138]. Therefore, it is suspected that the nano-scale bismuth oxide (Bi2O3) may display satisfactory NRR properties on account of its intrinsic characteristics and huge surface area, which has never been studied before. Yang and coworkers [51] reported their recent experiments proved that the flower-like β-Bi2O3 (Fig. 11c) was an efficient N2 fixation electrocatalyst with preeminent selectivity. In 0.1 M Na2SO4, the β-Bi2O3 nanoflower attained an NH3 yield of 19.92 μg h−1 mgcat. -1 and a high FE of 4.3% at −0.8 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 11d). Meanwhile, it also exhibited preferable electrochemical stability and durability. The β-Bi2O3 was a flower-like structure with many open petals, which owned a larger surface area for better catalytic performance. Our group [118] prepared bismuth-based free-standing electrodes by decorating Bi2O3 nanoplates homogeneously on free-standing exfoliated graphene (Bi2O3/FEG) (Fig. 11e). The Bi2O3/FEG exhibited excellent electrocatalysis performance and stability for NRR in neutral media, attributed to the synergistic effect of the strong interaction between Bi 6p band and the N 2p orbitals, binder‑free nature of the electrodes, large surface area and facile electron transfer through the graphene nanosheets. These two works not only provide us with high-efficiency NRR catalysts but also serve as a guide for the application of bismuth oxide in electrocatalysis. Due to the strong interaction between the Bi 6p energy band and the N 2p orbital, the surfaces of the Bi-based catalysts are prone to adsorb N2 molecules. By changing the synthesis method, manufacturing defect sites in the metallic Bi can improve the Bi nitrogen reduction performance. Oxygen-rich vacancies on the surface can adjust the charge distribution and act as an active center for the adsorption of N2 molecules. However, the number of defects and the concentration of OVs cannot be determined, whose formation mechanism and its effect on nitrogen reduction activity, are still unknown. The stability of bismuth oxide is poor. It can be considered to improve its stability by changing its electronic structure, element doping and amorphization strategy. At present, there are few studies on the application of antimony in NRR, and the mechanism of antimony to NRR still needs to be further proved. 4 Strategies to enhance the NRR performance Despite rapid advances achieved in electrochemical N2 reduction by using main group metal-based materials as catalysts, the unsatisfactory conversion efficiency including a limited FE and low NH3 yield rate remains a major challenge for scientists. The electrocatalytic performance of NRR catalysts intrinsically depends on their surface structures and electrons. Therefore, more electrocatalysts can be developed by rational design and preparation of advanced catalysts. Various strategies can be used for designing promising main group metal-based NRR catalysts by increasing the adsorption of nitrogen, catalytic active sites and catalyst surface area, such as defect engineering, ion incorporation, structural manipulation, composition regulation, crystallographic tailoring, interface regulation, and so on. Exposing more active sites and the larger specific area are critically important for enhancing the Faradaic efficiency and NH3 yield. Reduce the size of the catalyst is one attractive approach for exposing more active sites and the large specific areas to facilitate N2 adsorption and reduction. During the past three years, numerous nanoclusters/nanocrystals and nanoparticles of main group metal-based materials have been widely used for NRR applications, including Sn [27], SnS2 [101], SnO2 [49], Bi [26], Bi2O3 [51], et al. Compared with the nanoparticles, quantum-dot-based catalysts (QDCs) and single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become the most charming candidates in NRR electrocatalytic reactions. At present, some noble-metal based/rare-metal based SACs and QDCs have been used for NRR, demonstrating extraordinary catalytic performance, such as Ru @ nitrogen-doped carbon (NC), Au @ g-C3N4, but relevant researches of SACs and QDCs based on main group metal element are rare. Reducing the size of the main group metal-based element electrocatalysts to SACs or QDCs will effectively improve its electrocatalytic performance. Another efficient approach for exposing more active sites and the larger specific areas is precisely modulating the morphology. For example, we can use 1D nanostructures can be used to offer large specific areas, guide transfer pathways and facilitate electron transport. While 2D nanosheets are also extremely attractive morphology due to its ultrahigh specific area and high exposure of surface atoms, which is convenient to be modified and functionalized by element doping or vacancy engineering. Porous nanostructures with appropriate pore size and pore density are beneficial to accelerate the transfer and diffusion of the reactants to some extent and increase the active areas in the internal and outer surfaces of the catalyst by geometric multiples. Hollow structures or cage structures can confine the pivotal reaction intermediates or reactants in the inner space, which is more beneficial to increase their concentration in the rate-determining steps [10]. As Nazemi and coworkers [139] reported that Au hollow nanocage exhibited a high FE of 30.2% at −0.4 V (vs. RHE) and an impressive NH3 production rate of 3.9 μg h−1 cm−2, significantly more than those of Au nanostructures with other morphologies (such as Au nanocubes, Au nanospheres and Au nanorods), demonstrating the superiority of cage structures in the electrocatalysis of NRR. In view of this point, designing and synthesizing main group metal-based catalysts with precise morphology by hard/soft templates or template-free methods for NRR is an effective way to boost their NRR performances. For crystalline materials, facets are crucial for their catalytic performances, and different facets have different atomic arrangements, exposing different active sites. For instance, Pt (411) [140], Pd (111) [141] and BiOCl (001) [142] facets have displayed outstanding electro/photocatalytic activity. According to the reported theoretical calculation results, favorable active sites of catalysts are more likely to exist on the stepped facets rather than flat terraces [143]. To this end, main group metal elements and their corresponding compounds have the potential to adjust their NRR electrocatalysis performance by facet engineering for their multitudinous crystal types and facets. Compared to their crystalline counterparts, amorphous catalysts possess abundant active sites due to the unsaturated coordination sites for boosting the N2 reduction performance. For example, Chen and co-worker [105] designed a main group metal-based hybrid catalyst, Bi4V2O11/CeO2 (BVC-A), by decorating amorphous Bi4V2O11 on CeO2 for electrocatalytic NRR. Compared with its crystalline counterpart (BVCC), BVC-A showed outstanding NRR performance (v NH3: 23.21 μg h−1 mg−1, FE: 10.16%) for localizing electrons in BVC-A strengthened for π back-donation, conducing to an efficient N2 activation and facilitating N≡N dissociation. However, the low chemical stability seriously affects the practical application of amorphous catalysts. Developing new approaches to fabricate long-term stability main group metal-based amorphous catalysts is tremendously required in the future. Further, it is widely believed that surface defects have played a vital part in enhancing the NRR performances of electrocatalysts. Defect engineering, including vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping and exposed active edge sites, can effectively regulate the above properties. Nowadays, various vacancies have been introduced into the catalysts, including O vacancies (OVs), S vacancies (SVs) and N vacancies (NVs), and acted as major adsorption and active sites for reducing the activation energy barriers and accelerating the catalytic reactions [117,128,144–149]. Recently, catalysts with enriched SVs have been widely employed to accelerate N2 adsorption and activation. For example, Chu et al. [48] reported an efficient electrocatalytic N2 reduction at SVs on Mo-doped SnS2 nanosheets. The authors claimed that the presence of the Mo/SVs could induce plenty of accumulated electrons that can be easily transferred into the anti-bonding orbitals of the adsorbed N2 molecules, leading to an easier cleavage of the N≡N bond. Meanwhile, the SVs and Mo-dopant created remarkable electronic states near the Fermi level, bringing a higher conductivity than that of SnS2, which boosted the electrocatalytic NRR kinetics by promoting the proton-coupled electron-transfer process. By rationally introducing the SVs to Mo modified SnS2 nanosheets, the obtained catalyst presented a distinguished enhanced NRR activity (vNH3: 41.3 μg h−1 mg−1 at −0.5 V (vs. RHE), FE: 20.8% at −0.4 V (vs. RHE), which are among the best SnS2-based NRR electrocatalysts to date. Enlightened by this study, a series of efficient main group metal-based NRR electrocatalysts will be fabricated via defect engineering. Another effective method to regulate the electrocatalytic performance is the heteroatom doping that can tailor the chemical composition and electronic structures, as well as manipulate surface features, thereby reducing the energy the barriers for the key reactions [61,88,150–152]. To obtain more active sites and a more convenient electron transfer, some nonmetal heteroatoms (such as P, S, Cl, B, N) have been doped into carbon materials catalysts, metal oxides and oxide-hydroxides [153–155]. For example, Mukherjee and co-workers [124] used N-doped carbon (NPC) as a kind of NRR catalyst and confirmed that the pyridinic-N in it acted as the critical part to increase the N2 adsorption and the N≡N dissociation, thus promoting the NH3 production significantly. Chu et al. [61] developed an efficient NRR electrocatalyst by doping F into SnO2 mesoporous nanosheets on carbon cloth (F-SnO2/CC). DFT calculation revealed that F-doping could readily modify the electronic structure of SnO2 to improve its conductivity for an increased positive charge on active Sn active sites, leading to the lowered reaction energy barriers and a boosted NRR activity. In addition to nonmetal doping, various dopants of metal atoms (e.g., Fe, Mo, and Zr) had been widely employed for increasing the NRR catalytic activities. It was found that metal ions-doping would lead to a redshift of the photoresponse and reduce the electron-hole recombination, resulting in enhancing the transfer of charge carriers. The doping strategy can open up an efficient pathway to develop the desired main group metal-based NRR electrocatalysts. Edge engineering, as a novel strategy to manipulate NRR activity, is crucial to regulate the growth kinetics and morphological evolution of 2D materials, affording a difference of edge structures and donating variety electronic structures and functionalities [156–158]. For example, by using MXene as the catalyst, Wang et al. [64] proved that the edge planes with exposed Ti sites were the active site of NRR through experiment and theoretical calculation. The absorbed N2 at the middle Ti on the edge plane required an activation barrier of 0.64 eV for the first step to form [M-Ti]*NNH. However, the basal planes of MXene with terminal oxygen have to overcome a higher energy barrier (0.85 eV) to convert nitrogen into ammonia. Therefore, Ti located in the middle of the edge plane could significantly improve the electrocatalytic activity of NRR. Zhang and coauthors [159] found that the edges of MoS2 were the pivotal active sites for the polarization and activation of the N2 molecules, but the basal planes had little effect on NRR reaction. A similar conclusion was demonstrated that the exposed edge sites of Bi nanosheets were conductive to adsorb and activate the N2 molecules [127], while the basal plane of Bi nanosheets was relatively inert. Therefore, edge evolution in 2D materials is highly cried for designing promising and high-performance main group metal-based NRR 2D catalysts. 5 Summary and outlook In this review, we briefly summarized the research results of main group metal-based catalysts used in electrocatalytic NRR and compared their Faraday efficiency and ammonia yield. Table 1 shows the comparison results of various main groups of metal catalysts. It can be seen that the main group of metal materials have excellent nitrogen reduction performance, but it is still a great challenge to design an effective NRR catalyst and construct an excellent NRR electrochemical system. At present, electrochemical nitrogen reduction mainly has such problems as high potential, poor efficiency, low ammonia yield and ammonia pollution, which need further in-depth study in the future. The electrocatalytic NRR of main group metals is an effective way to achieve NH3 synthesis, but there are still several key problems to be solved: (i) Among the alkali metal elements, the lithium-mediated method has high Faraday efficiency and ammonia yield, but the reaction requires high temperature, and the process is complicated. Future research can achieve efficient nitrogen fixation by optimizing the reaction conditions. Li+ and K+ can effectively inhibit the HER, and they are often used as the electrolyte, but this universal mechanism of alkali metal ions needs to be further proved. At ambient conditions, there is less research on alkaline earth metals, which future research can be put on. (ii) Experiments have proved that aluminum complexes have nitrogen reduction properties. Based on this, it can be considered to study whether complexes of other metal elements also have nitrogen reduction properties, and their reaction mechanism should be studied. This may be a novel method for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction. At present, the research on gallium is still in the theoretical calculation, and the specific performance needs to be proved by experiments. The catalytic activity of SnO2 is relatively weak, and the nitrogen reduction performance is mainly improved by element doping. It can be considered to improve the electronic structure of Sn-based materials through strain engineering and defect engineering methods to obtain more active sites. Bismuth-based materials have defect sites, but the effect of the number of defects and the mechanism of defect formation on nitrogen reduction activity is not yet known, and the mechanism of antimony on NRR has yet to be proved. (iii) The reaction pathway of NRR has been studied in-depth and predicted from the perspective of theoretical calculation. However, the formation of basic reactions and intermediates has not been demonstrated by more convincing experiments. View from this respect, some in-situ characterization techniques, such as in-situ X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS), aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), spherical aberration corrected transmission electron microscopy (ACTEM), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) by synchrotron radiation and in-situ synchrotron radiation (SR) techniques are very effective in detecting transient states in the process of NRR, which can directly reveal the pathway of nitrogen reduction reaction and the formation of intermediate products. Therefore, in situ characterization techniques can be used to observe the catalytic active sites on the surface of the catalyst and provide guidance for the development of efficient NRR electrocatalyst. (iv) In the process of NRR, ammonia contamination is everywhere, such as the environment (ambient air and human breath), experimental instruments and reagents (including beakers, electrolytes, Nafion membranes, electrodes, etc.), as well as high purity feed gases (Ar, 14N2 and 15N2). Therefore, the experimental process should be conducted in an air-tight reaction chamber to eliminate the interference of laboratory atmosphere and human breath. For items exposed to the surface, it should be cleaned with dilute H2SO4 and then thoroughly rinsed with ammonia-free water before use. In addition, for high purity gases, a gas purification device prior to the gas inlet is necessary. In order to ensure the reliability of the experimental data, a set of control experiments should be carried out for each catalyst tested in Ar, 14N2 and 15N2 atmospheres. (v) It is necessary to confirm whether the source of ammonia is NRR or contaminations from NRR process for the relatively low ammonia yield rate of most NRR published results. At present, 15N2 isotopic labeling experiments are considered to be the most efficient method to determine the source of nitrogen. When isotope tracer tests are performed, the existence of NH3 and nitrogen oxides in isotope nitrogen should be checked in advance. At the same time, the yield of ammonia should also be quantified on the basis of isotope experiments. For the quantitative experiment of ammonia, at least two kinds of tests should be used to quantify the product to enhance the credibility of the experimental data. In addition, the influence of some cations on the detection results should be considered in the detection process to avoid greater errors. (vi) The design of main group metal catalysts can be divided into two types, one is to improve the surface activity, and the other is to improve the intrinsic activity. Since the activity of the catalyst is affected by the size effect and the crystal structure, the surface activity of the catalyst can be adjusted through crystal plane adjustment and morphological size engineering, so that the catalyst exposes more active sites, thereby improving the nitrogen reduction performance. In addition, the activity of the material is also affected by the electronic structure. The electronic structure of the electrocatalyst can be modified by methods such as defect engineering, heteroatom doping, adjustment of the internal electric field and surface modification, thereby improving nitrogen fixation activity. Therefore, it is of great significance to classify the newly developed NRR electrocatalysts and analyze the design principles of their corresponding materials for these works can provide a new way for the rational design and the selection of high-performance NRR electrocatalysts.
